description:
Beta vulgaris subsp. vulgaris, commonly known as the common beet or garden beet, is a subspecies of the beet plant that belongs to the Amaranthaceae family. It is a biennial herbaceous plant that is cultivated for its edible, fleshy root and leaves.

The plant has a taproot that can grow up to 30 cm in length and 10 cm in diameter. The leaves are large, green, and may have reddish-purple veins or stems. The flowers are small, greenish-yellow, and are arranged in dense, spike-like inflorescences.

Beta vulgaris subsp. vulgaris is widely grown for its nutritional value, as the roots and leaves are rich in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants. The roots can be consumed raw, cooked, or pickled, and the leaves can be used as a leafy vegetable.

This subspecies is believed to have originated in the Mediterranean region and has been cultivated for thousands of years. It is now grown extensively worldwide, with major production areas in Europe, North America, and Asia.
